abstract.value: John Louis Spivak (1897-1981) was a writer, journalist, and communist, mostly active in the 1920s and 1930s. This collection contains four photographs of Spivak.

p.value: Identification of item, date; John L. Spivak Photographs; PHOTOS 114; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.
Materials found in collection; provenance is unknown. The accession numbers associated with this gift are 1950.200 and NPA.2003.032.

John Louis Spivak, born June 13, 1897 in New Haven, CT, was an American journalist, who wrote articles and books on the rise of fascism, anti-Semitism, and the problems of the working class. Spivak wrote for the <emph render="italic">Daily Worker,</emph> <emph render="italic">New Masses</emph>, <emph render="italic">Ken</emph>, and<emph render="italic">the Call</emph>, the paper of the American Socialist Party, in addition to other other publications. During the rise of McCarthyism, Spivak wrote under pseudonyms, including Monroe Fry. His book credits include <emph render="italic">Georgia Nigger</emph> (1933),  <emph render="italic">Europe Under the Terror </emph>(1936), <emph render="italic">Secret Armies: the New Technique of Nazi Warfare</emph> (1939), <emph render="italic">Honorable Spy: Exposing Japanese Military Intrigue in the United States</emph> (1939), <emph render="italic">Shrine of the Silver Dollar</emph> (1940), <emph render="italic">Sex, Vice and Business</emph> (1959), and his autobiography, <emph render="italic">A Man In His Time</emph> (1967). He passed away on September 30, 1981 in Philadelphia, PA.
The collection contains four undated sepia-toned black and white prints, all portraits of John Spivak.
